results.title: Film making
results.brief_description: Films designed for school orientated learning have brought a new impact and excitement to learning previously unavailable in the classroom. In this investigation, the actual production of such a film is followed from beginning to finished product. It goes from covering the idea, script, costing, cameraman, director, crew, actors, titles, lettering, animation, editing, narration and music.

results.title: Film graphics: abstract aspect of editing
results.creator_credit: Cine Qua Non-Bartholomus, Paul Aratow and Barry Spinello
results.brief_description: With pictures, animation and quotations from classical cinema, this film shows some of the basic structural principles of film composition and editing. Extracts from BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN, UN CHIEN ANDALOU, and MAN WITH A MOVIE CAMERA, show the use of abstract graphic structure in film editing.

results.title: Film exercise
results.creator_credit: University of Auckland. School of Fine Arts and Rodney Charters
results.brief_description: This first film by a young New Zealand art student uses the motorcycle as a sex symbol in the lives of the “beat” generation…a girl’s infatuation with a motorcycle and its rider. This film was made as a design project at the School of Fine Arts, University of Auckland, and makes interesting use of various film techniques.

results.title: Film editing: interpretation and evaluation
results.brief_description: Contrasts the work of three Hollywood editors. Shows that the manner in which the film is sequenced, determines the dramatic effect. Firstly we see the film exactly as shot for a dramatic sequence, showing all scenes from various angles. Following these are three editing interpretations of the sequence by different editors. Demonstrates how, in assembling the shots, by omitting and shortening others and by different juxtaposition, the editor may control the dramatic construction. Looks at how a scene from the television series “Gunsmoke” is interpreted by different editing.

results.title: Film continuity
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Eric Halliday and Peter Thompson
results.brief_description: This film conveys the importance of technical, pictorial and narrative continuity and pre-planning for these. It also notes continuity of screen direction such as awareness of movement in the frame, eye lines and reverse shots. The function of the “continuity girl” or script supervisor is explained. Script by Caroline Stanton. This film is suitable for upper secondary students.

results.title: Film Australia: immigration
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Oasis DVD, Paul Byrnes and Penelope McDonald
results.brief_description: The Australian Migration scheme and Film Australia were both set up just after World War II and were under the one minister. Hand in hand they set about promoting and encouraging migration through the film medium. Films where also made to encourage acceptance of migrants for Australians. To this day the Film Australia Collection holds over 100 immigration films. This interesting and informative DVD presents edited versions of eight of the collections most important films. The films cover a period of time from the forties to the nineties with a contemporary short documentary containing interviews with some of the participants and the film makers of each of the eight films. “Film Australia Immigration” also presents a series of clips arranged by subjects such as language, food, and identity. An extremely fascinating and authoritative exploration of immigration in Australia.
